description: Dive into "Romantic Escapes in Enchanting Marseille" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Romantic Escapes in Enchanting Marseille

places.generalDescription: Parc national des Calanques, established in 2012, is a stunning natural reserve located in the Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur region. Encompassing both land and sea areas, it spans over 8,500 hectares of land across Marseille, Cassis, and La Ciotat, along with 43,500 hectares of marine territory. This park boasts remarkable biodiversity with numerous protected terrestrial and marine species.

sources.snippet: The last town is a resort town, just 25 minutes by train from Marseille St-Charles station, and serves as a gateway to the Calanques National Park. From the town center, you can walk to the nearest Calanque Port Miou (water grotto) in just 30 minutes. A bit further is Calanque du Port Pin, about an hour from Cassis.
sources.shortName: What to See and Do in Marseille, France

sources.snippet: Visualize jagged limestone cliffs dropping into secret pebble beaches, which are lapped by the aquamarine waters of the Mediterranean Sea, and you'll start to get a picture of the Parc National des Calanques. Although many travelers view this national park from the sea, others say the hiking is absolutely magical too. Recent visitors said pictures don't do the Parc National des Calanques justice, swooning that its cliffs, inlets and beaches are breathtaking.
sources.shortName: 9 Best Things to Do in Marseille

sources.snippet: Calanques National Park is a must-visit destination for nature lovers. It‚Äôs a protected area that features stunning limestone cliffs, crystal-clear water, and beautiful beaches. You can take a boat tour or a hike through the park with your partner and enjoy the breathtaking views.
sources.shortName: Love in the Air: Top 5 Date Spots for a Romantic Evening in Marseille

sources.snippet: The Calanques National Park, a stretch of coast between Marseille and Cassis, away from the city‚Äôs buzz, is an absolute must. Spectacular views, aquamarine waters, limestone cliffs leading to secret pebble beaches. Put on your bathing-suit and dive in.
sources.shortName: Make The Most Of One Day In Marseille

sources.snippet: Here you‚Äôll find a veritable paradise where you can swim, sunbathe and stroll for long afternoons, weather permitting. Summer is the best time to go. We recommend the calanques of Sormiou and Morgiou.
sources.shortName: Week end romantique en France : O√π partir

sources.snippet: Embark on a 3.5-hour tour in the Calanques National Park with your friendly guide to discover the 3 emblematic Calanques of Marseille
sources.shortName: Things to do in Marseille : Museums and attractions

places.name: Parc national des Calanques

reviews.text: Wow is all I can say. It's accessible with a bus from Marseille (30-45mins) and from the bus stop you just walk and you'll get to this. Just be careful if you're taking a dip in the lake Cus the rocks are slippery and there are sharp edges. Had a cut when I swam but all is good! Definitely worth a trip here x
If you are here for tourism, you should definitely check this place. There are so many trekking points. And what a beautiful path! You will definitely fall in love with this place.

I can highly recommend climbing the Massif Marseilleveyre if you're into hiking. Steep climb, but astounding views of virtually the entirety of Marseille and surrounding Calanque. The unique limestone landscape was really cool, great for photography

places.generalDescription: The Basilica of Notre-Dame-of-la-Garde at Marseille is a grand basilica located at the city's highest point, featuring a golden statue of the Virgin Mary by Lequesne. For those seeking a luxurious stay, there are options like the InterContinental Marseille and Sofitel Marseille Vieux Port with breathtaking views of the Old Port. Alternatively, visitors can opt for boutique accommodations such as Le Petit Nice Passedat or C2 Hotel for a more intimate experience.

sources.snippet: The Basilica Notre-Dame de la Garde sits on the highest point in Marseille and overlooks everything. It was completed in 1864 in a Roman-Byzantine style ‚Äì domes, mosaic, multi-coloured stones. It‚Äôs a wonderful place to take a loved one, to picnic, to take in the views, and for couple selfies.
sources.shortName: The Most Romantic Places In Marseille France

sources.snippet: Next up, wander over to the Basilica Notre-Dame de la Garde. It‚Äôs one of two iconic striped √† l‚ÄôItalien style in the city, quite unusual in France. The climb up the hill could count as a hike, but the reward is a panoramic view of the ocean.
sources.shortName: What to See and Do in Marseille, France

sources.snippet: Get your sneakers on and climb the hill (and the many steps) to reach the highest building in Marseille: the Basilica Notre-Dame de la Garde, built by King Fran√ßois I, at 150 m above sea level to protect the city from invaders. See the Byzantine architecture, the sublime views or have a romantic little picnic (in that case, get supplies since there are no shops nearby). Feeling less energetic?.
sources.shortName: Make The Most Of One Day In Marseille

sources.snippet: Discover one of the symbols of Marseille: the Basilica of Notre-Dame de la Garde. Nicknamed the ‚ÄúGood Mother‚Äù, it overlooks the city and protects its inhabitants. The view is truly worth the diversions, whatever the time of day, but the sunsets you can admire here are a marvel for the eyes.
sources.shortName: Week end romantique en France : O√π partir

sources.snippet: Notre-Dame de la Garde is a beautiful basilica located on a hill overlooking the city. It‚Äôs a popular tourist destination, but it‚Äôs also a great spot for a romantic date. You can take a walk up the hill, and when you reach the top, you‚Äôll be rewarded with a breathtaking view of Marseille.
sources.shortName: Love in the Air: Top 5 Date Spots for a Romantic Evening in Marseille

sources.snippet: No romantic weekend is complete without at least one sunset. Perched atop a hill, this iconic basilica offers panoramic views of Marseille and the Mediterranean. Share this breathtaking moment with your loved one, capturing the beauty of the city in the warm hues of the setting sun.
sources.siteName: Staycity Aparthotels - Half Apartment, Half Hotel
sources.shortName: The Perfect Romantic Weekend for Couples in Marseille

sources.snippet: From the winding alleys leading to the Old Port to the steep summits of Notre-Dame de la Garde, Marseille sets the perfect scene for a romantic getaway. Throughout this three-day journey in the Phocaean city, discover its breathtaking panoramas and savor the Provencal cuisine.
sources.shortName: What to do as a couple for three days in Marseille?

sources.snippet: Undoubtedly one of the most emblematic spots of the city and famous for its sunsets, it is nonetheless romantic!. So come and enjoy this breathtaking view of the city and the harbor, under the watchful eye of the Bonne M√®re to dazzle your partner's eyes!
sources.shortName: TOP 8 of the most romantic spots in Marseille<!-- -->

sources.snippet: Perched atop a hill, Notre-Dame de la Garde is Marseille‚Äôs most iconic landmark. Couples can enjoy panoramic views of the city and the shimmering sea, making it a fantastic spot for a romantic photo session.
sources.shortName: Celebrate Day of Love in Marseille, France: A Romantic Getaway with Stunning Views and Unforgettable Experiences for Honeymooners and Couples

sources.snippet: Book a guided tour to Pays de Sault and dive into the lavender fields in bloom. Visit Gordes and Roussillon, two of the most beautiful villages in France.
sources.shortName: Things to do in Marseille : Museums and attractions
9 Best Things to Do in Marseille

places.name: Notre-Dame de la Garde

reviews.text: The sculptures are beautifully crafted, and the scultpure on the top of the building with the gold emblems adds an elegant charm. It was truly delightful to witness the timeless beauty of a ancient place of worship. Definitely a picture-perfect spot as you will have a view of the entire city. The public bus brings you to the parking lot. Prepare to walk up a few flights of stairs to get to the building and enjoy the breathtaking view.

Beautiful cathedral on hill overlooking Marseille.  We actually walked here from the drop-off point of the free cruise terminal bus, was around 4kn - 1 hour but that's by a load of other great sites so is not a hardship.  Stunning building inside and put, obviously tied to the maritime theme.  Currently undergoing some renovation work so the main tower is shrouded in scaffolding but that doesn't detract too much from the majesty of the place.  There's also amazing, 360 views of the sprawl of Marseille and the Med from here so 100% worth a visit.  Entry to the cathedral and grounds are free with only the museum being chargeable.

The cathedral sits at the highest hill and point in the city.
Multiple levels with a restaurant and cafe.
The interior is beautifully designed with intricate details.
The outside areas and decks of the cathedral offer panoramic views of Marseille, the Mediterranean Sea, and the surrounding landscape, and can clearly see Chateau D'if in the distance.  There was construction üöß going on at the time we visited as well.
A must visit for Marseilles, as it is the main attraction in the city and best part free entry.

places.address: Rue Fort du Sanctuaire, 13006 Marseille, France

places.generalDescription: Mucem - Museum of Civilizations of Europe and the Mediterranean is a striking venue that opened in 2013, offering captivating exhibitions on the history and cultures of the Mediterranean region. The museum's contemporary architecture provides stunning sea views and houses world-class exhibits showcasing the intriguing stories behind European and Mediterranean civilizations. Its vast collection includes Neolithic and contemporary art, football memorabilia, graffiti, antique tarot cards, sound recordings, and unique artifacts like mermaid-shaped bread.

sources.snippet: The Museum of European and Mediterranean Civilisations (or MuCEM for short) is a relatively new addition to the local museums. The building is sublime and a real focal point of the rejuvenation that‚Äôs taken place in Marseille in recent years. It‚Äôs linked to the Panier, one of the oldest districts in Marseille and its neighbour, the old Fort Saint-Jean, by spectacular walkways that will take your breath away.
sources.shortName: The Most Romantic Places In Marseille France

sources.snippet: It‚Äôs an impressive building at the water‚Äôs edge and the flagship for Marseille‚Äôs redevelopment from run-down waterside city to chic Mediterranean destination. Inside, you‚Äôll find temporary and permanent art exhibitions covering everything from football, recycling habits, and love‚Ä¶. Tempting tasty treats await in the two restaurants, both the brainchild of local chef, G√©rald Passedat.
sources.shortName: The Best Things to do in Marseille, France

places.name: Museum of European and Mediterranean Civilisations

reviews.text: The many exhibits was fantastic. I love that there is still this learning and development from history. I visited in March which is part of the slow season, but there are still many school tour groups that pass through. The museum has some beautiful outside spaces and magnificent views of the city of Marseille.

An incredibly located museum of Mediterranean cultures lets you discover them from a very interesting perspective. The temporary exhibitions are very good. The building is new, but connected by a bridge to an old fort, which adds to the experience. Marseille and its amazing charm can become a bit more understandable after a visit to this museum. The caf√© in the fort is also worth recommending. It's worth stopping by the gift shop - wonderful selections, especially in the book section, as well as beautiful handicrafts.

Remarkable place. The idea itself is great - due to inaccessability of the original site, and in order to preserve it for the generations to come, the replica of the cave was made. The length of the tour is  good, the location of the building is appropriate (next to the sea), the price is adequate. Overall, an excellent experience. Would highly recommend!

places.generalDescription: Parc Bor√©ly is a stunning ch√¢teau estate turned public park, featuring 18th-century formal gardens, fountains, and a picturesque lakeside caf√©. Spanning over 17 hectares, the park boasts various garden styles including French, English, botanical, and Chinese gardens. It also houses a racecourse and a waterfront promenade along Plage Bor√©ly.

sources.snippet: The Parc Bor√©ly is one of Marseille‚Äôs secrets that locals would love you not to know about. Jog along the dry river bed, towards the sea and do a few circuits of the park and its stylish mansion. If you‚Äôre looking for romance, there‚Äôs no better place.
sources.shortName: The Most Romantic Places In Marseille France

sources.snippet: Louis Bor√©ly, a local merchant, returned home rich from Egypt in 1767 with the idea of building a country house, which would ‚Äúsurpass all others in terms of size and splendour‚Äù. Now called Park Bor√©ly, it‚Äôs the place for in-the-know locals to escape the heat and noise of the city, although not always the crowds. Classified nationally as ‚Äúone of the most remarkable gardens in France‚Äù, feted French author Marcel Pagnol fondly recounted childhood visits here.
sources.shortName: The Best Things to do in Marseille, France

sources.snippet: Just a stone‚Äôs throw from the Prado beach, the magnificent Parc Bor√©ly welcomes you all year round for a moment of relaxation in this little corner of nature. Discover its 17 hectares of French and English-style gardens, its botanical garden, its lake (where you can take a boat trip), and its Museum of Decorative Arts, Earthenware and Fashion. It‚Äôs an idyllic setting for a romantic stroll.
sources.shortName: Week end romantique en France : O√π partir

sources.snippet: Escape the city buzz and enjoy a peaceful picnic in the beautifully landscaped Parc Bor√©ly. With its lush gardens, fountains, and serene atmosphere, it‚Äôs an idyllic spot to celebrate love in nature.
sources.shortName: Celebrate Day of Love in Marseille, France: A Romantic Getaway with Stunning Views and Unforgettable Experiences for Honeymooners and Couples

places.name: Parc Bor√©ly

reviews.text:
Beautiful lush green spacious public park in heart of city.
Suited for Family day out , parties and sports activities.

Fountain, chateau, beach in 10min walk.
Big park, beautifully maintained and nice little lakes. Interesting animals too! Water rats, ducks and peacocks!

One of favourite places in marseille. Very relaxing and quiet. Suitable to take a walk, or a quick run. Kids will love the ducks, otters, and the other birds that roam freely in their natural habitat. They have small play areas for smaller kids. The views are beautiful.

places.address: Av. du Parc Bor√©ly, 13008 Marseille, France

places.generalDescription: Nestled near the iconic Vieux-Port and easily reachable via public transport, Les Terrasses du Port is a vibrant shopping destination in Marseille that offers more than just retail therapy. This bustling center features a diverse array of shops showcasing both local and international brands, making it a perfect spot for fashion enthusiasts. But what truly sets Les Terrasses du Port apart is its stunning rooftop terrace, which spans an impressive 2,600 square meters.

sources.shortName: Valentine‚Äôs day in Marseille

places.name: Les Terrasses du Port

reviews.text:
Clean and well maintained Shopping Center, average in size with a great, I would even say spectacular view at the port side from where Corsica Linea ferry are leaving towards different destination of Corsica or North Africa.
Plenty of brands, including Apple Store, available at the hand, along with some options of restaurants. It is worth while to visit.

Nice quiet and safe spot to do your shopping and take pictures of the ocean as well as the ships. Nearby to other attractions in this upcoming area. Easy to get to from the city centre. Just a short tram ride. This was my first time but a positive experience. The staff at the entrance are friendly and helpful.

Considering we are in Marseille. They have a lot of guards which helps makes you feel safe. They are very friendly and happy to help with any questions you have.

Store wise you have got a massive selection. All of which are very clean and the overall shopping mall has great presentation.

Parking isn't ever going to be easy based on it's location and cannot be helped.

Lots of busses and free trams nearby tho

places.generalDescription: Palais Longchamp, a grand monument built in the mid-1800s, stands as a tribute to the completion of an impressive canal construction project in Marseille. The building's architecture combines Baroque, Roman, and Oriental styles and features a stunning sculpture fountain at its center. Visitors can explore the Musee des Beaux-Arts de Marseille and Le Museum d'Histoire Naturelle located within the palace complex.

sources.snippet: During a cholera epidemic in the 1800s, the city‚Äôs leaders had to find a way to get a clean water supply into the city. The complicated plan to build over 52 miles (85 km) worth of aqueducts from the Durance river took years and to celebrate, the magnificent Palace Longchamp was built to commemorate the achievement. Today it‚Äôs one of the top things to do in Marseille for families ‚Äì you can easily while away an entire day, visiting the small Natural History Museum, the botanical gardens, the observatory and the many playgrounds.
sources.shortName: The Best Things to do in Marseille, France

sources.snippet: The incredible Palais Longchamp, known also as the ch√¢teau d‚Äôeau, offers something for everyone: romantic strolls in the botanical gardens, many playgrounds for your little ones, a caf√© at the top or a visit to the Natural History Museum of Marseille. When walking in the gardens, you can even take a selfie with a 120-year-old Siberian elm in the background. The Palais de Longchamp is also amazing at night when the building and the fountains are magically illuminated.
sources.shortName: Make The Most Of One Day In Marseille

places.name: Palais Longchamp

reviews.text: Stunning palace in a nicer area of Marseille. Very scenic and picturesque as you're walking up. Lots of great photo opportunities and there's gardens and a playground at the top behind the pillars. Easy to access to via tram. Definitely don't miss this if you're in Marseille.

One of the best locations in the city. A must visit. A very nice view of the city. The foundation is an amazing and outstanding architectural masterpiece. The park inside is very peaceful and enjoyable. You can find two museums, a cantina and a old zoo simulation.

A beautiful monument which houses two museums: the Beaux-Arts and the Natural History Museum. The latter was small (free) but packed full of information on life and the earth. Great for kids but not only... The park itself was a little scruffy and neglected, notices indicated that it was undergoing an extensive restoration plan.

places.generalDescription: Ch√¢teau d'If is a 16th-century island castle and former prison located in the Bay of Marseille. Famously known as the setting for Alexandre Dumas' novel, The Count of Monte Cristo, this historic fortress has captured the imagination of many visitors. While some may claim that the novel's story is based on real events, it's undeniable that the island's scenic beauty and its role as a former state prison make it an intriguing destination.

sources.snippet: Ch√¢teau d'If is a 16th-century fortress, commissioned by King Francois I, set atop the smallest island in the Frioul archipelago less than a mile from Marseille. It was later used as a prison, considered ideal for its isolated, escape-proof location (similar to San Francisco's Alcatraz). Visitors to Marseille often travel by boat to this beautiful and mysterious monument, especially since it inspired the prison setting of Alexandre Dumas' famous book, "The Count of Monte Cristo.
sources.shortName: 9 Best Things to Do in Marseille

sources.snippet: Just a 20-minute boat-ride from Marseille‚Äôs port, and you‚Äôll find yourself at Ch√¢teau d‚ÄôIf, a former fortress and a later prison from which nobody escaped due to the surrounding strong tidal waters. Except for Alexandre Dumas‚Äô fictional protagonist, of course, in The Count of Monte Cristo (1844). The paths are uneven and there‚Äôs little shade, so make sure to wear comfy shoes, a hat and sunscreen.
sources.shortName: Make The Most Of One Day In Marseille

sources.snippet: Embark on a boat trip to the iconic Ch√¢teau d'If, a historic fortress on a small island with breathtaking views of the Mediterranean. Whether you're interested in literature, history, or you‚Äôre simply seeking a unique experience, the journey to Ch√¢teau d'If is the perfect way to experience some historic charm with your other half. View this post on Instagram
sources.siteName: Staycity Aparthotels - Half Apartment, Half Hotel
sources.shortName: The Perfect Romantic Weekend for Couples in Marseille

sources.snippet: Ch√¢teau d‚ÄôIf is a famous fortress located on a small island off the coast of Marseille. It‚Äôs a popular tourist destination, but it‚Äôs also a great place for a romantic date. You can take a boat ride to the island, explore the fortress, and enjoy the stunning views of the Mediterranean Sea.
sources.shortName: Love in the Air: Top 5 Date Spots for a Romantic Evening in Marseille

places.name: Ch√¢teau d'If

reviews.text:
Great mini excusion and fantastic view to the city. Plan this trip ahead, for us the LaBateau line was sold out, but got tickets with Icard Maritime. The fort was less interesting for me, only some of the information board was translated to English.
Also note, that depending on the traffic you may not get on the first return ship. For us that was an extra hour of queueing on the dock. But since everyone picks the return boat based on the time spent on the island, nothing is garanteed. We left with the last boat out, 2 hours after arriving.

A hauntingly beautiful place, steeped in legend and history. Visiting Ch√¢teau d'If feels like walking through the pages of The Count of Monte Cristo. The cells, the sea views, the isolation - everything echoes Dumas' story of betrayal, escape, and revenge. But even beyond the novel, the fortress itself is fascinating, with stunning views of the Marseille coast. Mysterious, powerful, unforgettable.
Amazing ferry ride out to the Ch√¢teau. Amazing place to visit! Loved the dome at top where the voice echos when you talk. We also loved the old graffiti from the prisoners.

places.address: Embarcad√®re Frioul If, 1 Quai de la Fraternit√©, 13001 Marseille, France

places.generalDescription: Expansive, well-maintained lawn around the Palais du Pharo with serene city & water views.

sources.snippet: In the midst of nature's embrace, Parc √âmile Duclaux provides a serene oasis for couples. Enjoy a romantic stroll through lush greenery and savor the tranquility that fosters deeper connections.
sources.shortName: Marseille Romance A Stroll Through Love‚Äôs Harbor

places.name: Parc √âmile Duclaux

reviews.text: Beautiful scenic location, kids park, and amazing architecture. It was peaceful and a good place to get some great photos.

This is a must visit for people to see an amazing panorama of the area.
Magnificent views.
Nice park with great views of the Old Port. I did not go inside, but walked around. There was some public restrooms though not the most beautiful. Worth a visit if walking around the old port area.

places.generalDescription: Calanque de Port Pin is a stunning natural area featuring rocky formations, pine trees, and sandy beaches. It offers picturesque hiking trails and beautiful shingle beaches. The surrounding area boasts luxurious accommodations with breathtaking views of the Old Port from terraces. Visitors can also explore nearby attractions such as Ile Verte, Calanque du Mugel, and Plage L'Arene.

sources.snippet: From the town center, you can walk to the nearest Calanque Port Miou (water grotto) in just 30 minutes. A bit further is Calanque du Port Pin, about an hour from Cassis.
sources.shortName: What to See and Do in Marseille, France

places.name: Calanque de Port Pin

reviews.text: What an amazing place to see. The turquoise water is absolutely stunning. Be careful thought the rocks are incredibly slippery. Well worth the trip from wherever you are in france!
GORGEOUS! Absolutely worth the hike there. -highly recommend the panoramic way even though it's 30 minutes longer - the views are stunning! The way to the beach is a big difficult, but really doable.

It's a bit of a hike to get here (wear a good pair of shoes) and make sure you bring plenty of water, especially on a hot day. But the views along the walk are stunning and the beach is well worth the effort. It's a popular beach, but if the main beach is too busy you can scramble along the rocks to find your own quieter spot. Swimming is lovely and you can dry off in the sun after. The circular walk around to the next Calanques is definitely recommended for the views, but there is a bit of clambering involved.

places.generalDescription: The H√¥tel Dieu Intercontinental Marseille is a luxurious five-star hotel that was once a hospital for over 800 years before being transformed in 2013. Located in the heart of Marseille, it offers stunning views of the Basilica Notre-Dame de la Garde and is just a short walk from the Museum of European and Mediterranean Civilisations (MuCEM). The hotel's prime location provides easy access to the Old Port and its lively atmosphere.

sources.snippet: This is by far the best option for luxury hotels in Marseille!. The five-star hotel is based up the hills of Le Panier, rewarding guests with magnificent views across the city centre. There is a large spa centre with an indoor pool, Turkish baths and various holistic treatments on offer.
sources.shortName: Wondering Where to Stay in Marseille? [2023

places.name: H√¥tel Dieu Intercontinental Marseille

reviews.text:
I had an excellent stay at the InterContinental Hotel in Marseille. üåüüåüüåüüåüüåü
The location is perfect, and the facilities truly live up to a 5-star standard. The indoor pool is beautiful, though you do need to make an appointment and the access is limited to 1 hour per session. Aside from that small detail, the gym was well-equipped, and the rooms were spacious, comfortable, and well maintained. Overall, a fantastic experience and highly recommended.

We stayed here in early May as part of our wedding anniversary celebrations from Sunday to Monday.  The room was lovely with a separate dressing section n fabulous bathroom.

My only complaint was that the air-conditioning was not working properly. It was quite hot in Marseille that weekend n the hotel was not able to reduce the temperature of the rooms.  As I am of a certain age, I struggle with my own internal furnace. In spite of raising the matter with reception, nothing really was done to rectify the issue. This affected my sleep n my overall experience at the hotel. It was an expensive sleep deprived stay.
The most beautiful hotel in Marseilles. Staff was extremely helpful and friendly. Grounds were exquisite. Location cannot be beat. Close to everything we wanted to see/do. I would stay again.

places.generalDescription: AM par Alexandre Mazzia is renowned for its creative approach to flavors and dishes, offering one of the best culinary experiences in Provence-Alpes. The Michelin-starred restaurant serves visually stunning dishes, using natural colors and shapes to create truly unique plates. The bright, minimalist space showcases artfully presented contemporary cuisine that lingers with flavors from around the world.

sources.shortName: 21 Best Things To Do In Marseille For 2025, France, By Local Experts

places.name: AM par Alexandre Mazzia

reviews.text:
Dining at AM par Alexandre Mazzia is more than just a meal-it's like watching a carefully orchestrated show unfold, where every course is a new act filled with surprises. From start to finish, the experience was immersive, thoughtful, and full of unexpected delights.

The wine pairing was exceptional, perfectly complementing each dish and elevating the flavors in ways I hadn't anticipated. A few dishes held an element of surprise-unique textures, bold flavors, and creative combinations that kept me engaged throughout the meal.

While every course was beautifully executed, my personal favorite was the miso soup. It had incredible depth, rich umami, and a comforting yet refined balance that truly stood out.

I am not a dessert person, so I wasn't a big fan of the dessert. I didn't finish cos I was too full by then.

If you appreciate innovative, sensory-driven dining, AM par Alexandre Mazzia is an absolute must-visit. The attention to detail, artistry, and seamless blend of flavors make for an unforgettable experience.

One of the best dining experience I ever had. A voyage as they call it. The wine pairing from the sommelier was also outstanding as he took time to listen and adjust his choices based on my preferences.

Exceptionally creative, expressive cuisine
a sensory journey weaving cultural identity with technique.
Open, inclusive setting: no pretentiousness-just artful food and warm conviviality.
Stimulating pace: rapid succession of dishes keeps curiosity and taste buds engaged.

AM par Alexandre Mazzia is a daring, unforgettable experience that redefines modern haute cuisine.
It's an artful explosion of flavors, deeply personal storytelling through food, and a refreshingly informal approach to 3-star service.
Best suited for adventurous diners seeking innovation, intensity, and a taste journey off the beaten path.

places.generalDescription: Calanque de Sugiton is a stunning narrow inlet with steep limestone cliffs and crystal-clear waters, accessible via a scenic hiking trail. The Tour d'Orient, also known as the belvedere, offers an incredible panoramic view of the calanque and surrounding areas. Visitors can enjoy swimming and snorkeling at sandy and small-pebbled beaches like Saint-Esteve, Sormiou, Sugiton, and En-Vau.

sources.snippet: If you‚Äôre looking for a longer, more romantic walk, the Calanque d‚ÄôEn Vau, the Calanque de Marseilleveyre or the Calanque de Sugiton are well worth a visit!
sources.shortName: Valentine‚Äôs day in Marseille

places.name: Calanque de Sugiton

reviews.text:
This is a small beautiful calanque with a couple of nice beaches. It's very easy to get here from Marseille, 30-40 minutes walk from Luminy. Due to this fact it suffers from overtourisme, so  the Marseille authorities introduced daily quotas in high season - 500 visitors per day.

Luckily when I visited this calanque, there were not many people because of the mistral. So I could enjoy it in peace and quiet.
One of the most beautiful Calanques I've ever seen. The view is truely one of the best ! It makes you feel like you're swimming in paradise, on a tropical island !! ü§©ü§©ü§©
Beautiful hikes and view. However getting to the beach didn't feel as way as everyone described it

places.generalDescription: Marseille's Old Port, also known as Vieux Port, holds centuries of history and cultural significance. Established by the Phoenicians around 600 BC, it thrived as a hub for Mediterranean trade and was later integrated into the Roman Empire. The port's forts, Saint-Nicolas and Saint-Jean, stand as guardians with a rich medieval past. Visitors can explore historical buildings from various periods in PACA, including well-preserved Roman structures like amphitheaters and baths.

sources.snippet: Begin your romantic weekend by meandering along the Vieux-Port, Marseille's historic Old Port, the iconic and historic heart of the city. The sounds of lapping waves and the gentle breeze from the Mediterranean create a serene atmosphere, ideal for a leisurely stroll hand-in-hand. View this post on Instagram
sources.siteName: Staycity Aparthotels - Half Apartment, Half Hotel
sources.shortName: The Perfect Romantic Weekend for Couples in Marseille

places.name: Old Port of Marseille

reviews.text: We visited there in the end of March. It is very center of the city where you can find many restaurants, souvenir shops, soap shops which is what Marseille is famous for. You can enjoy the view with a cup of coffee either in a cafe across the port or by walking around the port under warming sunlight.

Don't miss this place if you visit Marseille in the first time. I visited late June when the summer starts and the temperature is about 33+c during day time. There are seafood restaurants, cafe, Asian restaurants around so you can take some walks and have lunch or dinner.
we walk around the old port at 7am and it was spectcular. the crowd build up slowly. evening sunset is also nice but busier.

places.generalDescription: Vallon des Auffes is a picturesque fishing port located just south of Marseille's center. This charming inlet features colorful sea captains' cabins, traditional fishing boats, and a cluster of buildings that cascade down to the water's edge. It offers a glimpse into the city's maritime heritage and provides stunning views of the sunset. The area is home to several renowned restaurants serving bouillabaisse, including the Michelin-starred Epuisette and the historic Chez Fonfon.

sources.snippet: Tucked away from the bustling city, Vallon des Auffes is a picturesque fishing harbor where time seems to stand still. The sight of colorful boats, traditional Marseille houses, and the calm sea makes this the perfect spot for a quiet, romantic stroll. As the sun sets, the golden hues reflecting on the water create an intimate and breathtaking scene.
sources.shortName: Celebrate Day of Love in Marseille, France: A Romantic Getaway with Stunning Views and Unforgettable Experiences for Honeymooners and Couples

sources.snippet: In a setting similar to the Italian Cinque Terre, the Vallon des Auffes is the quintessential typical Marseille port that offers a magical view of the Mediterranean and the sunset. From small outdoor tapas bars, to rooftop restaurants or dining with your feet in the water, all options are available to find YOUR perfect moment!
sources.shortName: TOP 8 of the most romantic spots in Marseille<!-- -->

sources.snippet: n the evening, let yourself be seduced by the romantic atmosphere of the Vallon des Auffes at sunset, and enjoy a gourmet dinner at  L‚ÄôEpuisette, with the murmur of the waves as background music. You can also swim there in the summer and go for a drink at Viaghji di Fonfon !
sources.shortName: What to do as a couple for three days in Marseille?

places.name: Vallon des Auffes

reviews.text: Gorgeous little corner! One of the bars makes proper espresso coffee too. Clean and lovely to visit. To one side is access to the sea where I would start my swim back to plage des Catalans. Kid friendly around that part and great for adults to venture out.

Charming harbor in the downtown
This place deserves a visit. Quite close to the old port (shorter than 30' walking), you'll find a charming harbor seemingly entering deep in the downtown. You can walk along the wharfs enjoy a glass or a nice dinner. If you go on 150 meters on the right side you'll reach the seafront with a nice view on the bay, especially at sunset.
Do not try to get very close by car, it's almost impossible to park.

Visiting Vallons des Aufons, the charming fishing village in Marseille, was an absolutely fantastic experience. Nestled along the picturesque coast, this little place radiates an authentic and welcoming atmosphere that left a lasting impression.

Strolling through its quaint streets, I was captivated by the genuine warmth of the locals and their rich fishing traditions, the aroma of grilled fish wafted from seaside restaurants, tempting my taste buds.

places.generalDescription: Une Table au Sud, meaning A Table in the South, is a renowned restaurant located in the heart of Marseille's Vieux Port. This sophisticated dining spot offers breathtaking views of the harbor and serves a blend of imaginative local and global cuisine with a contemporary twist. Established in 2013, it has since earned a Michelin star under the guidance of chef Ludovic Turac and his team.

sources.snippet: Le Petit Nice - Passedat is the only Relais et Ch√¢teaux in the city, with a gourmet table rated three stars by Michelin.
sources.shortName: Week end romantique en France : O√π partir

places.name: Une Table au Sud

reviews.text: Great dinner experience! I absolutely loved the vibe as it was matching the quay outside with seafood and water decor. The staff were very polite, professional, and  with eye to detail. The food itself was very pleasant. We had the 7 course set menu and I loved everything on it. The most, I loved the blue lobster and the desserts were nice as they were fresh, fruity, and not too heavy. They also served 3 types of bread, which was a bit much for me personally as matching 3 breads with 7 courses is too much. But, the first bread with olives was absolutely delicious as it was warm, tasty, and very soft. Overall, great place that I highly recommend!!!

A very nice and enjoyable lunch, in the heart of Marseille, with spectacular views on Vieux Port. The cuisine has deep Proven√ßal roots with some clins d'≈ìil to Armenia (the young Chef, Ludovic Turac, was born in Marseille but has an Armenian grandmother). It is full of the flavors from this cosmopolitan city and uses various spices from around the Mediterranean (every dish comes with a sampler of the spices used in its composition). The cooking is modern, but without the gimmicks that ¬´¬†modern cooking¬†¬ª sometimes entails. What is modern is the freshness of the ingredients (whose origins are always specified), the clarity of the preparation, the accuracy of the cooking, and the lightness of the dishes. We had the menu ¬´¬†essentiels¬†¬ª, which feature two of the Proven√ßal basics: aioli and bouillabesse. And they both taste like aioli and boyillabesse, but not in a traditional and roborative way. They are more like dreams or reminiscences of aioli and bouillabesse. The ¬´¬†cabillaud nacr√©¬†¬ª melts in the mouth and the aioli sauce, which is lightly emulsified, offers a pleasant accentuation that does not overpower the delicate taste of the fish. The ¬´¬†soup de roche¬†¬ª that accompanies the ¬´¬†rouget¬†¬ª of the bouillabesse, is strong and deep, as it suits to such kind of soup, but again, it does not take the main role. In both cases, there is a subtle balance between the various elements giving a feeling of plenitude but not of fullness. The meal unfolds, like a pleasant journey in the calanques, with its palette of colors and surprises. The cassis white wine was a perfect match to the rouget and the bouillabesse. The service is discreet and efficient. The tableware is original and well harmonized with the food. In short, a southern table, but rejuvenated and looking to the future. We will definitely come back.

The best meal I had in Marseille, Michelin restaurant 2024.
I was taking their lunch set menu which was ‚Ç¨85.
All the food was very tasty and creative.
The olive bread did surprise me a lot, I can't stop myself finishing the whole bread.
The fish was excellent, it was so tender and fresh. The dessert was very creative.
An absolutely outstanding restaurant which you shouldn't miss!

places.generalDescription: L'√âpuisette is an upscale seafood restaurant located in Marseille, offering a sophisticated dining experience with a focus on Mediterranean-inspired cuisine. Overlooking the crashing surf and the port of Vallon des Auffes, this elegant waterside establishment has gained renown for its exquisite fixed-price menus and extensive wine list.

sources.snippet: n the evening, let yourself be seduced by the romantic atmosphere of the Vallon des Auffes at sunset, and enjoy a gourmet dinner at  L‚ÄôEpuisette, with the murmur of the waves as background music. You can also swim there in the summer and go for a drink at Viaghji di Fonfon !
sources.shortName: What to do as a couple for three days in Marseille?
Valentine‚Äôs day in Marseille

places.name: L'√âpuisette

reviews.text: Incredible nice restaurant just a little bit outside the bustling city center. We opted for a 9 course menu and enjoyed every single course. The service was very attentive and the sommerlier did an amazing job suggesting pairing wines. I will definitely come back

Highly recommended to have your lunch here.
L'Epuisette is a restaurant right next to Mediterranean Sea.
You can see Ch√¢teau d'If by the window seats.

The service was nice. We are from Taiwan and waitress said ‚Äú‰Ω†Â•Ω‚Äù to us with smile.

And the most remarkable was their Aspic of Bouillabaisse which was a aspic reach of the flavor of Bouillabaisse.

The second remarkable was ‚ÄúRed mullet, cooked and raw Tomato water and Kimchi butter.‚Äù
We are from Asia and familiar with Kimchi. I must say this was the best Kimchi dish. The flavor was balanced and really tasty. It was out of the way how Asian use Kimchi in dishes. Really surprised. And the red mullet was cooked perfectly.

Finally, the petit four cart was cute. You can choose anything you wanted.

Reasonable price, high quality cooking, beautiful sea view.

We had the Marius set menu for lunch. The food was ok but definitely not worth a Michelin one-star status.

The protagonist of the menu is Bouillabaisse but by the forth dish, it gets a bit boring and uninspiring.
The Rock fish soup is too salty for our taste and we had to take it with bread to balance it out. The main course, different types of fish poached in soup, is no good; fish was overcooked and had no flavor that you would expect from fresh fish. The soup which the fish is soaked in too similar to the rock fish soup (or is the same?) they served in previous course. The soup's taste was strong and too salty that it overshadowed whatever little flavor that was in the fish. The two courses were basically the same, except for the fish added to it.
The dessert from the trolley are all no good either.

The staffs were standoffish and pretentious. They had a ‚Äúget-down-to-business' attitude and had prioritized the food's presentation than caring about the customers. Despite the beautiful view, we did not find the atmosphere relaxing nor the lunch enjoyable.

places.address: 158 Rue du Vallon des Auffes, 13007 Marseille, France

places.generalDescription: The Marseille Soap Museum showcases artifacts and demonstrations on soapmaking, as well as custom soap souvenirs. It's a charming venue with interesting displays that will interest anyone interested in this traditional craft.

sources.snippet: Immerse yourselves in the world of fragrance and tradition at The Marseille Soap Museum. Discover the art of soap-making, a sensory experience that ignites the senses and allows you to craft lasting memories together.
sources.shortName: Marseille Romance A Stroll Through Love‚Äôs Harbor

places.name: Le Mus√©e du Savon de Marseille

reviews.text:
Visiting the Marseille Soap Museum was a fantastic experience! For only ‚Ç¨2.50, we were treated to a beautiful and educational journey through the history and tradition of Marseille soap-making. The museum itself is charming, with informative displays that detail the process of creating the famous soap, as well as the significance it holds in local culture.

One of the highlights was learning about the traditional techniques and ingredients that make Marseille soap so unique. The exhibits were well-organized and easy to follow, providing a great mix of history, science, and local craftsmanship. It was fascinating to see how this centuries-old tradition continues to thrive today.

As a lovely bonus, each visitor is given a 100g bar of soap as a souvenir, which made the experience even more special. The soap smells amazing and is a wonderful reminder of our visit. It's a great touch that adds excellent value to the already affordable entry price.

The museum staff was also very welcoming and knowledgeable, which made our experience even more enjoyable. Overall, the Marseille Soap Museum is a must-visit for anyone interested in the city's rich heritage. A perfect blend of history and hands-on learning!

Wonderful museum about the fascinating history of Marseille soap. It is a big passion for us. Maybe it would be nicer to mention some of the big companies that lead the Marseille soap market in the past and now. It is obvious that la Licorne has an interest in not mentioning them but a museum of the history should include the ones that started it. Fer a Cheval, La Corvette, Marius Fabre etc..

I really enjoyed the small but informative soap museum near the port in Marseille. It's a quick visit - I learned a lot about the history and process of soap-making - and for just ‚Ç¨2.50, you get a free bar of Marseille soap, which feels totally worth it. It's tiny, but a charming spot to check out if you're nearby!

places.address: 25 Quai de Rive Neuve, 13007 Marseille, France

places.generalDescription: La Mercerie is a trendy neobistro and wine bar located in Marseille's Noailles neighborhood. The restaurant features a mix of distressed walls, industrial-style lighting, and designer chairs, creating an impossibly hip atmosphere. British chef Harry Cummins crafts subtle and imaginative dishes using local, seasonal ingredients that cater to vegetarians and those with food allergies. The restaurant offers a three-course lunch menu and a five-course dinner menu served indoors or on the outdoor terrace.

sources.shortName: What to do as a couple for three days in Marseille?

places.name: La Mercerie

reviews.text: Had an absolutely delicious dinner at La Mercerie last night. The secret menu consisted of four exquisite seasonal dishes, of particular note the ricotta filled ravioli with morel mushrooms and green peas - it was springtime with every bite, followed by an excellent cheese plate and a divine dessert. The wine card is substantial and evenly priced. We sat at the bar which allows for unobstructed views of the goings on in the kitchen. The staff is warm and charming. Highly recommend La Mercerie. Thank you for a lovely evening.

Wow. Such an amazing experience and definitely worth it. Their 5 course menu is perfected, delicious and doesn't leave you uncomfortably full. The waitstaff were so knowledgeable and helpful, we had some lovely conversations especially during the wine paring for each course.

There was a unique event where local winemakers were dining at the restaurant and we were able to see who made the wines we drank. One even came around pouring his wine and sharing stories with us all. Truly an amazing experience.

We sat at a table but saw the chef engaging with people sat at the bar and telling stories of the food to them so I would recommend that for sure!

yesterday we had dinner at La Mercerie to use the American Express dining credit abroad.
at first staff told us it was ‚Äúreservation only‚Äù but then they let us sit down as long as we agreed to a surprise five course menu.
we ordered the house wine to go with it.
both, the menu and the wine, were very delicious.
the staff was very attentive and friendly.
in total, we paid ‚Ç¨165 (‚Ç¨65 per menu) for two people.
